title: Toward a Psychology of Democratic Well‑Being
text: ###A curated, living repository that integrates cross‑national, longitudinal, and experimental evidence on how democratic contexts shape psychological basic needs (autonomy, competence, relatedness) and, in turn, citizens’ well‑being and civic engagement. Built for cumulative, open, and policy‑relevant science.

title: Toward a Psychology of Democratic Well‑Being
text:
Concept note


Purpose
The Hub curates datasets, metadata, and reproducible code connecting democratic quality, psychological need dynamics, well‑being, and civic attitudes. It offers public aggregates for transparency and governed access for partner microdata.






Rationale



Democracies aim to create conditions for human flourishing, yet democratic discontent is rising. By mapping when systems support or thwart citizens’ needs, we clarify why democracies sometimes enhance mental health—and why, under threat, citizens may prefer autocratic solutions.



Scope

Datasets: cross‑national surveys; national panels; experiments; validated short scales.
Metadata: codebooks, translations, invariance reports, sampling frames, weights, changelogs.
Analytics: preregistered pipelines for harmonization, SEM/MLM, experiments, visualization.
Access: public aggregates + restricted microdata (DTA/DTUA).
Governance: authorship/citation norms, ethics & GDPR templates, annual DOI releases.

title: Contributing Guidelines (v0.1)
text:
Contributing Guidelines (v0.1)
Intake checklist - [ ] Ethics approval ID and consent language - [ ] Codebook (CSV) with variable names, labels, scale bounds - [ ] Translation tables (if cross-national) - [ ] Provenance metadata (who, when, where) - [ ] Quality checks (missingness, attention checks)
Review & Authorship - Submissions are reviewed for harmonization, quality, and ethics. - Authorship follows CRediT. Data providers are offered co-authorship when substantive intellectual contributions are made.

title: Data Access Policy (v0.1)
text:
Data Access Policy (v0.1)
Tiers 1. Public aggregates (summary tables, figures).
2. Partner microdata (requires DTA/DTUA, ethics approval, and project alignment).
3. Embargoed (ongoing studies; internal only).
Usage & Citation
- Cite the hub with its DOI and version (see CITATION.cff).
- Co-authorship follows CRediT roles and the project’s contribution guidelines.
Privacy & Ethics
- GDPR-compliant pipelines; unit-level identifiers removed or encrypted.
- Each dataset must include an ethics statement and approved protocol ID.
